Knowledge Point: Polynesian languages are known to be very flexible in use of nouns and verbs: many words seem to be used both as nouns and verbs. This is also true for Rapa Nui. In \REF{ex:3.1} below, poki ‘child’ occurs in a noun phrase (preceded by the article te) which is subject of the clause; in \REF{ex:3.2}, it occurs in a verb phrase (preceded by the imperfective marker\is{Aspect marker} e) which is the clause predicate:
Content 1: \gll He pōrekoreko \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} \ꞌi Tāhai. | \gls NTR born:RED ART PL child at Tahai | \glt ‘Children were born in Tahai.’
Content 2: \gll Mai te hora era ō\ꞌoku \textbf{e} \textbf{poki} nō \ꞌana... | \gls from ART time DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV child just CONT | \glt ‘From the time when I was a child...’

Knowledge Point: Nevertheless, I will argue that there are good reasons to maintain a lexical distinction between noun and verbs. That is, words are defined as noun or verb in the lexicon. This does not mean that all occurrences of these words are completely and unambiguously nominal and/or verbal. Lexical verbs very commonly enter into constructions which have certain nominal features; less frequently, lexical nouns are used in constructions with certain verbal features (as in \REF{ex:3.2} above). Moreover, many words are specified as both noun and verb in the lexicon, as \textit{\mbox{{\ꞌ}a{\ꞌ}amu}} in (\ref{ex:3.3}–\ref{ex:3.4}) above.
Content 1: \gll Mai te hora era ō\ꞌoku \textbf{e} \textbf{poki} nō \ꞌana... | \gls from ART time DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV child just CONT | \glt ‘From the time when I was a child...’
Content 2: \gll ¿He parauti\ꞌa \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} nei? | \gls ~PRED truth ART story PROX | \glt ‘Is this story true?’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} ia e mātou i te \ꞌati ta\ꞌato\ꞌa nei o tātou o Rapa Nui. | \gls NTR tell then AG 1PL.EXCL ACC ART problem all PROX of 1PL.INCL of Rapa Nui | \glt ‘We told about all the problems we have on Rapa Nui.’

Knowledge Point: Firstly: despite the flexibility in the use of nouns and verbs, the large majority of noun phrases have a nucleus denoting an entity, while an overwhelming majority of verb phrases have a nucleus denoting an event. While all action words can be used in nominal phrases, many entity words are never used in verb phrases, or only in very specific, uncommon contexts. For example, the word oho ‘go’ is very often preceded by the imperfective marker e, but the word taŋata ‘man’ is never preceded by this particle in the text corpus. Other words, like \textit{\mbox{{\ꞌ}a{\ꞌ}amu}} in (\ref{ex:3.3}–\ref{ex:3.4}) above, are commonly used both as noun and as verb, but with a different sense. Somehow generalisations like these should be accounted for in the grammar. To assume one large class of words, which can be indiscriminately slotted into noun or verb phrases, does not do justice to actual usage.
Content 1: \gll ¿He parauti\ꞌa \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} nei? | \gls ~PRED truth ART story PROX | \glt ‘Is this story true?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} ia e mātou i te \ꞌati ta\ꞌato\ꞌa nei o tātou o Rapa Nui. | \gls NTR tell then AG 1PL.EXCL ACC ART problem all PROX of 1PL.INCL of Rapa Nui | \glt ‘We told about all the problems we have on Rapa Nui.’

Knowledge Point: A third argument that the apparent freedom of use does not imply the absence of lexical categories, comes from a rare phenomenon: very occasionally, words from other (minor) word classes are used as a noun or a verb. For example, a pronoun may occur in the nucleus of a verb phrase as in \REF{ex:3.5}; demonstrative particles may be the nucleus of a verb phrase, as in \REF{ex:3.6}:\footnote{\label{fn:91}Postverbal era\is{era (distal)!postverbal} \textit{{\ꞌ}ā} indicates a finished action (sometimes equivalent to a perfect or pluperfect).}
Content 1: \gll ¿Ko \ꞌite \ꞌā kōrua he aha i \textbf{mātou} ai? | \gls ~PRF know CONT 2PL PRED what PFV 1PL.EXCL PVP | \glt ‘Do you know what we did?’
Content 2: \gll —¿Ku oti \ꞌā? —¡\textbf{Ko} \textbf{era} \textbf{\ꞌā} ta\ꞌa me\ꞌe. | \gls ~~~~~PRF finish CONT ~~~~PRF DIST CONT POSS.2SG.A thing | \glt ‘—Is it finished? —I’m done (lit. something like ‘there is your thing’).’

Knowledge Point: Syntactic: the presence of a determiner does not necessarily mean that the phrase is entirely nominal. The nucleus of such a phrase may control verbal arguments:\footnote{\label{fn:93}\citet{Waite1994}, working in a generative framework, captures this insight by proposing that D (=determiner) in \ili{Māori} can take not only NP complements, but VP and AdjP as well. This means that a verb may occur in a nominal context (DP) while retaining its verbal character.} in \REF{ex:3.7} below, the subject of vānaŋa has the agent marker e; in \REF{ex:3.8}, runurunu is followed by a direct object marked with the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i.
Content 1: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa} e te vi\ꞌe... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART speak AG ART woman | \glt ‘When the woman had finished speaking...’
Content 2: \gll He turu mai ia ki te hare hāpī koia ko \textbf{te} \textbf{runurunu} mai i te rāua tūava. | \gls NTR go_down hither then to ART house learn COM PROM ART gather:RED hither ACC ART 3PL guava | \glt ‘They went down to school, while picking (lit. with the picking) guavas.’

Knowledge Point: The phrase may also contain other VP elements like directionals\is{Directional}, such as mai in \REF{ex:3.8}. These elements do not appear in ordinary noun phrases, i.e. phrases headed by entity words like taŋata ‘man’ or hare ‘house’. In conclusion, a phrase introduced by a determiner may still have certain VP characteristics.
Content 1: \gll He turu mai ia ki te hare hāpī koia ko \textbf{te} \textbf{runurunu} mai i te rāua tūava. | \gls NTR go_down hither then to ART house learn COM PROM ART gather:RED hither ACC ART 3PL guava | \glt ‘They went down to school, while picking (lit. with the picking) guavas.’

Knowledge Point: Semantic: despite the presence of a determiner, the nucleus may have a verbal sense, referring to an event rather than an entity. Even though it is preceded by a determiner, the verb may therefore have a different meaning from a real noun with the same form.\footnote{\label{fn:94}The same point is made by \citet[511]{Besnier2000} for \ili{Tuvaluan}.} This can be illustrated with the word vānaŋa, which may denote an action ‘to talk’, or an entity ‘word, spoken utterance’. In \REF{ex:3.9} vānaŋa denotes an event and occurs in a verb phrase (preceded by the aspect marker e); in \REF{ex:3.10} it denotes an entity and occurs in a noun phrase (preceded by the article te):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{mai} \textbf{\ꞌā} paurō te mahana ki a au. | \gls IPFV speak EMPH hither CONT every ART day to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Every day he speaks to me.’
Content 2: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’

Knowledge Point: Clearly, in \REF{ex:3.9} vānaŋa is a verb, while in \REF{ex:3.10} it is a noun. So far, so good. In \REF{ex:3.7} above however, vānaŋa denotes an event, even though it is preceded by a determiner. It serves as the complement of oti, a verb which commonly takes a nominalised event word as complement. Thus, te vānaŋa in \REF{ex:3.7} is not nominal in the same way as te ŋā vānaŋa nei in \REF{ex:3.10}. Notice that this semantic difference correlates with certain syntactic differences: in \REF{ex:3.10}, vānaŋa is preceded by the plural marker ŋā, a noun phrase element; in \REF{ex:3.7} it is followed by a subject marked with the agentive e, something to be expected of a verb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{mai} \textbf{\ꞌā} paurō te mahana ki a au. | \gls IPFV speak EMPH hither CONT every ART day to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Every day he speaks to me.’
Content 2: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’
Content 3: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa} e te vi\ꞌe... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART speak AG ART woman | \glt ‘When the woman had finished speaking...’
Content 4: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa} e te vi\ꞌe... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART speak AG ART woman | \glt ‘When the woman had finished speaking...’
Content 5: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’
Content 6: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’
Content 7: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa} e te vi\ꞌe... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART speak AG ART woman | \glt ‘When the woman had finished speaking...’

Knowledge Point: Constructions such as \REF{ex:3.11} are only found with event words, not with entity words. If the underlined phrases were regarded as noun phrases because of the presence of the article, they would be undistinguishable from “normal” noun phrases, which never enter into this construction.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀ\ꞌana \textbf{te} \textbf{haka} \textbf{tere} i te henua. | \gls POSS.3SG.A ART CAUS run ACC ART land | \glt ‘He (was the one who) governed the country.’

Knowledge Point: We may conclude that it would be unsatisfactory to consider a word as noun whenever it is preceded by a determiner. Event words preceded by determiners may have either a nominal sense and nominal function, or a verbal sense and verbal function (possibly with verbal syntactic trappings). This suggests that we should make a distinction between \textsc{lexical nominalisation}\is{Nominalisation!lexical}, which turns a verb into a true noun, and \textsc{syntactic nominalisation}\is{Nominalisation!syntactic}, in which a verb is used as nucleus of a noun phrase, while retaining its verbal meaning and other verbal characteristics, such as the possibility to take verbal arguments. The examples above show that both occur in Rapa Nui: \REF{ex:3.10} is an example of lexical nominalisation\is{Nominalisation!lexical}, while \REF{ex:3.7} is an example of syntactic nominalisation\is{Nominalisation!syntactic}. These processes will be discussed in sections \sectref{sec:3.2.2} and \sectref{sec:3.2.3}, respectively.
Content 1: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’
Content 2: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa} e te vi\ꞌe... | \gls PFV finish DIST ART speak AG ART woman | \glt ‘When the woman had finished speaking...’

Knowledge Point: Between prototypical\is{Prototype} nouns and prototypical\is{Prototype} verbs lies a whole range of non-prototyp\-i\-cal\is{Prototype} constructions, as illustrated above. Any attempt to divide this area up by drawing a line separating the “noun area” from the “verb area” is arbitrary. However, for practical reasons I will use the term verb for any word which is lexically (i.e. semantically) a verb, and noun for any word which is lexically a noun. Thus, in the examples above, the underlined lexical item in (\ref{ex:3.1}–\ref{ex:3.3}) and \REF{ex:3.10} is called a noun, while the underlined word in \REF{ex:3.9} and \REF{ex:3.11} is called a verb. Vānaŋa is a verb when it denotes the action ‘to talk’, whether it occurs in a prototypical\is{Prototype} VP or in a phrase that also has nominal properties. When vānaŋa denotes an entity ‘word, utterance’, it is a noun. As these two senses are obviously related, the relation between the two can be defined as polysemy (one lexical item having two related but not identical senses) rather than homophony (two unrelated lexical items which happen to share the same phonological form).
Content 1: \gll He pōrekoreko \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} \ꞌi Tāhai. | \gls NTR born:RED ART PL child at Tahai | \glt ‘Children were born in Tahai.’
Content 2: \gll ¿He parauti\ꞌa \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} nei? | \gls ~PRED truth ART story PROX | \glt ‘Is this story true?’
Content 3: \gll Ka tai\ꞌo pūai \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{nei}: raŋi, rano, rapu. | \gls IMP read strong ART PL word PROX raŋi rano rapu | \glt ‘Read the following words aloud: raŋi, rano, rapu.’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{mai} \textbf{\ꞌā} paurō te mahana ki a au. | \gls IPFV speak EMPH hither CONT every ART day to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Every day he speaks to me.’
Content 5: \gll \ꞌĀ\ꞌana \textbf{te} \textbf{haka} \textbf{tere} i te henua. | \gls POSS.3SG.A ART CAUS run ACC ART land | \glt ‘He (was the one who) governed the country.’

Knowledge Point: These criteria tend to converge into the same direction; for concrete words, this is usually the same direction as suggested by the semantics of the word: an entity word is usually modified by NP elements and may take a possessor\is{Possession}; an event word is usually modified by VP elements and may take canonical arguments. In other words, nouns and verbs tend to show prototypical\is{Prototype} behaviour.\footnote{\label{fn:97}\citet[96]{Croft2000} points out that the meaning of words tends to shift towards the unmarked sense associated with their syntactic use: action words used in referring expressions tend to denote an object typically associated with the activity (e.g. ‘learn+NOM’ {\textgreater} ‘school’); object words used as a predicate tend to denote an action typically associated with the object (e.g. ‘baggage+V’ {\textgreater} ‘to pack’).} The same syntactic criteria can now be used to assign abstract words (for which the semantics do not provide a strong clue) to a word class. For an example of how syntax can help to categorise an abstract word, see the discussion on \REF{ex:3.14} in \sectref{sec:3.2.2.1} below.
Content 1: \gll A au e haka \ꞌite atu ena i tō\ꞌoku \textbf{mana\ꞌu}, i tō\ꞌoku \textbf{ŋaro\ꞌa} \textbf{iŋa}. | \gls PROP 1SG IPFV CAUS know away MED ACC POSS.1SG.O think ACC POSS.1SG.O perceive NMLZ | \glt ‘I will make known what I think, what I feel.’

Knowledge Point: The causative\is{Causative} prefix haka\is{haka (causative)} (\sectref{sec:8.12}) turns a root into a verb. There are a few cases where haka + root is lexicalised as something else than a verb (e.g. \textit{haka{\ꞌ}ou} ‘again’, hakanonoŋa ‘fishing zone’), but the vast majority of haka forms are verbs. However, like all verbs, they may take on certain nominal roles and function as a noun phrase head: see e.g. \REF{ex:3.29} below.
Content 1: \gll Ku mate atu \ꞌā a au \ꞌi te kata \ꞌi tū \textbf{haka} \textbf{paka} era i a ia. | \gls PRF die away CONT PROP 1SG at ART laugh at DEM CAUS conspicuous DIST ACC PROP 3SG | \glt ‘I laughed my head off (lit. died with laughing) because of his boasting.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Natural phenomena} Many natural phenomena\is{Verb!weather} (e.g. meteorological conditions) can be expressed as either noun or verb. The following pair of examples illustrate this for \textit{a{\ꞌ}a} ‘flood’: in \REF{ex:3.12} it is a verb with the flooded object as subject, in \REF{ex:3.13} it is a noun in idiomatic collocation with the verb rere ‘fly’.
Content 1: \gll Ku \textbf{a\ꞌa} \ꞌā te hare \ꞌi te vai. | \gls PRF flood CONT ART house at ART water | \glt ‘The house was flooded with water.’
Content 2: \gll He rere te \textbf{a\ꞌa}. | \gls NTR fly ART flood | \glt ‘The flood came up.’

Knowledge Point: The Rapa Nui lexicon has incorporated a large number of \ili{Spanish} borrowings\is{Borrowing} (\sectref{sec:1.4.2}). These are used cross-categorially with great freedom. For many \ili{Spanish}\is{Spanish influence} noun/verb pairs, Rapa Nui has borrowed one form, usually either the noun or the verb in the 3\textsuperscript{rd} sg. present, and this form is used as both noun and verb. Below are two examples from the text corpus.\footnote{\label{fn:103}See also \citet{Makihara2001Adaptation}, who gives many examples from a corpus of spoken texts.} In \REF{ex:3.15}, rivuho, originally a noun (Sp. dibujo ‘drawing’), is used as a verb; in \REF{ex:3.16}, the verb agradece (Sp. agradece ‘gives thanks’) is used as a noun.
Content 1: \gll Ku \textbf{rivuho} atu \ꞌā i tū \ꞌavione era. | \gls PRF drawing away CONT ACC DEM airplane DIST | \glt ‘They drew that airplane.’
Content 2: \gll Me\ꞌe huru kē tō\ꞌona \textbf{agradece} ki te hau nei he rapa nui. | \gls thing manner different POSS.3SG.O thank to ART race DIST PRED Rapa Nui | \glt ‘Her gratitude for this race, the Rapa Nui, is exceptional.’

Knowledge Point: Syntactic nominalisation\is{Nominalisation!syntactic} refers to constructions in which a lexical verb enters into a construction which has “some of the formal trappings of a noun phrase” \citep[65]{Clark1981}. As discussed in \sectref{sec:3.2.1.1}, no change in meaning is involved; the verb retains its verbal sense, while the phrase may retain VP characteristics. In Rapa Nui, the minimal criterion for nominalisation is that the verb is preceded by a determiner (see the inventory of determiners in \sectref{sec:5.3.1}). This is usually the article te\is{te (article)}, occasionally a demonstrative determiner, but it may also be the nominal predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}: see the discussion of \REF{ex:3.23} below.\footnote{\label{fn:104}Pace \citet[136]{Moyse-Faurie2011}: “In Polynesian languages, only the specific article may nominalise a verb phrase”.}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI rā noho iŋa \textbf{he} \textbf{tu\ꞌu} nō mai \textbf{te} \textbf{aŋa} o te nu\ꞌu pa\ꞌari ki tō\ꞌoku koro u\ꞌi. | \gls at DIST stay NMLZ PRED arrive just hither ART do of ART people adult to POSS.1SG.O Dad look | \glt ‘At that time the old people always came to see my father (lit. just arriving was the doing of the old people).’

Knowledge Point: Not all distributional facts are easily explained, though. Certain constructions take a suffixed nominalisation, even though they denote an event with temporal duration (e.g. the ko te V construction in (\ref{ex:3.24}–\ref{ex:3.25}) below). On the other hand, a reason clause may refer to one particular instance, yet contain a zero nominalisation (see \REF{ex:3.29}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ai} \textbf{iŋa} \textbf{\ꞌana} te kona mai ira e punua ena te naonao. | \gls PROM ART exist NMLZ CONT ART place from ANA IPFV hatch MED ART mosquito | \glt ‘There are still places from where the mosquito breeds.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{kimi} \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ohu} a nua. | \gls PROM ART search PROM ART shout PROP Mum | \glt ‘Mum kept searching and shouting.’
Content 3: \gll Ku mate atu \ꞌā a au \ꞌi te kata \ꞌi tū \textbf{haka} \textbf{paka} era i a ia. | \gls PRF die away CONT PROP 1SG at ART laugh at DEM CAUS conspicuous DIST ACC PROP 3SG | \glt ‘I laughed my head off (lit. died with laughing) because of his boasting.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Ko S te V} Much less common is the ko S te V construction: a topicalised subject marked by ko, followed by a zero nominalisation (see (\ref{ex:8.89}–\ref{ex:8.90}) on p.~\pageref{ex:8.89}).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira \textbf{ko} tū ŋā taina rikiriki nō era ō\ꞌona \textbf{te} \textbf{oho} ki te hāpī. | \gls because_of ANA PROM DEM PL sibling little just DIST POSS.3SG.O ART go to ART school | \glt ‘Therefore only her little brothers went to school.’
Content 2: \gll Te taŋata e mate tahi rō \ꞌā; \textbf{ko} koe nō, \textbf{te} \textbf{ora} \textbf{te} \textbf{oho}. | \gls ART person IPFV die all EMPH CONT PROM 2SG just ART live ART go | \glt ‘All people die, but you just keep on living.’

Knowledge Point: As he can precede both verbs (the aspect marker he) and nouns (the predicate marker he)\is{Aspect marker}, it may not be immediately obvious that \textit{he tu{\ꞌ}u} is nominalised. However, the further contents of the clause show that this is the case: the subject of the clause is te aŋa, which is not an argument of \textit{tu{\ꞌ}u}. Conversely, the Agent of \textit{tu{\ꞌ}u} is not expressed as subject of the clause, but as a genitive phrase after aŋa. (Another indication that the verb in this construction is nominalised is, that its object may be incorporated; see \REF{ex:5.128} on p.~\pageref{ex:5.128}.)
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI tō\ꞌona mahana he ai mai te aŋa he \textbf{\ꞌāua} \textbf{titi}, \ꞌo he \textbf{rau} \textbf{kato}. | \gls at POSS.3SG.O day NTR exist hither ART work PRED enclosure build or PRED leaf pick | \glt ‘On certain days there were jobs like making fences or picking leaves.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Ko te V} The construction ko\is{ko (prominence marker)} te + verb signifies that an action or situation is ongoing or persisting. In most cases a suffixed nominalisation is used, followed by the identity particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ana}\is{ana (identity)@{\ꞌ}ana (identity)}\textit{/{\ꞌ}ā}\is{a (identity)@{\ꞌ}ā (identity)}, as in \REF{ex:3.24}. Sometimes the identity particle is left out, in which case a zero nominalisation may be used, as in \REF{ex:3.25}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ai} \textbf{iŋa} \textbf{\ꞌana} te kona mai ira e punua ena te naonao. | \gls PROM ART exist NMLZ CONT ART place from ANA IPFV hatch MED ART mosquito | \glt ‘There are still places from where the mosquito breeds.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{kimi} \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ohu} a nua. | \gls PROM ART search PROM ART shout PROP Mum | \glt ‘Mum kept searching and shouting.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Reason clause} Finally, a construction with nominalised verb is sometimes used to express reasons (see (\ref{ex:11.258}–\ref{ex:11.259}) on p.~\pageref{ex:11.258}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Tu\ꞌu} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{hakaroŋo} ena ki te vānaŋa o te taote; \ꞌo ira koe i māuiui haka\ꞌou ena. | \gls POSS.2SG.O CONNEG listen MED to ART word of ART doctor because_of ANA 2SG PFV sick again MED | \glt ‘You didn’t listen to the words of the doctor, therefore you got sick again.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{kore} mo kai, \ꞌo ira au e taŋi nei. | \gls PRED thing lack for eat because_of ANA 1SG IPFV cry PROX | \glt ‘There is nothing (lit. the lack of things) to eat, therefore I am crying.’

Knowledge Point: For more examples, see \REF{ex:3.19} and \REF{ex:3.21} above.
Content 1: \gll Tō\ꞌona \textbf{noho} \textbf{haŋa} \ꞌi Ahu te Peu. | \gls POSS.3SG.O stay NMLZ at Ahu te Peu | \glt ‘He lived (lit. his living) in Ahu te Peu.’
Content 2: \gll Pē nei te \textbf{aŋa} \textbf{haŋa} o te rā\ꞌau nei. | \gls like PROX ART make NMLZ of ART medicine PROX | \glt ‘This is how you make (lit. the making of) this medicine.’

Knowledge Point: Notice however, that \REF{ex:3.35} does not refer to a specific instance either, yet it involves a suffixed form\is{Noun!verbal}.
Content 1: \gll He riva nō te \textbf{hī} \textbf{iŋa} ki te nu\ꞌu o mu\ꞌa \ꞌana i te siera. | \gls PRED good just ART to_fish NMLZ for ART people of before IDENT ACC ART sawfish | \glt ‘For the people of the past, fishing for sawfish was something nice.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Nominal predicates} With the nominal predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}, suffixed nominalisations are used (except in the construction he V te aŋa, see \sectref{sec:3.2.3.1.1} above, ex. \REF{ex:3.23}). This happens for example in titles as in \REF{ex:3.49}, in existential clauses\is{Clause!existential}, and in classifying clauses\is{Clause!nominal} as in \REF{ex:3.50}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI rā noho iŋa \textbf{he} \textbf{tu\ꞌu} nō mai \textbf{te} \textbf{aŋa} o te nu\ꞌu pa\ꞌari ki tō\ꞌoku koro u\ꞌi. | \gls at DIST stay NMLZ PRED arrive just hither ART do of ART people adult to POSS.1SG.O Dad look | \glt ‘At that time the old people always came to see my father (lit. just arriving was the doing of the old people).’
Content 2: \gll He \textbf{tu\ꞌu} \textbf{iŋa} mai o Hotu Matu\ꞌa | \gls PRED arrive NMLZ hither of Hotu Matu’a | \glt ‘The arrival of Hotu Matu’a’ (title of a story)
Content 3: \gll Te me\ꞌe nehenehe o te aŋa nei... he \textbf{aŋa} \textbf{iŋa} o te hi\ꞌo. | \gls ART thing beautiful of ART work PROX PRED make NMLZ of ART glass | \glt ‘The beautiful thing of this work was the making of the glass.’

Knowledge Point: However, the distinction between haŋa and -ŋa is by no means clear-cut. On the one hand, haŋa forms are used with nominal senses, especially in the sense of place, manner and time (see (\ref{ex:3.19}–\ref{ex:3.21}) above): noho haŋa means ‘epoch’, just like nohoŋa; \textit{{\ꞌ}iti{\ꞌ}iti haŋa}\is{hanza (nominaliser)@haŋa (nominaliser)} ‘small \textsc{nmlz} = infanthood’; piko haŋa ‘hide \textsc{nmlz} = hiding place’. On the other hand, -ŋa forms may be used with a verbal sense, just like haŋa forms:
Content 1: \gll Tō\ꞌona \textbf{noho} \textbf{haŋa} \ꞌi Ahu te Peu. | \gls POSS.3SG.O stay NMLZ at Ahu te Peu | \glt ‘He lived (lit. his living) in Ahu te Peu.’
Content 2: \gll Pē nei te \textbf{aŋa} \textbf{haŋa} o te rā\ꞌau nei. | \gls like PROX ART make NMLZ of ART medicine PROX | \glt ‘This is how you make (lit. the making of) this medicine.’

Knowledge Point: More generally, both suffixes occur in nominalisations used as subject, object, genitive, after prepositions, and in time clauses introduced by \textit{{\ꞌ}i}. The only construction in which haŋa never occurs, is the predicate construction ko te V (see (\ref{ex:3.24}–\ref{ex:3.25}) above). Speaker preference may play a role: it is telling that the Bible translation consistently uses iŋa, almost never haŋa\is{hanza (nominaliser)@haŋa (nominaliser)}. Apart from this, I have not been able to find a distinction between the two.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ai} \textbf{iŋa} \textbf{\ꞌana} te kona mai ira e punua ena te naonao. | \gls PROM ART exist NMLZ CONT ART place from ANA IPFV hatch MED ART mosquito | \glt ‘There are still places from where the mosquito breeds.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{kimi} \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ohu} a nua. | \gls PROM ART search PROM ART shout PROP Mum | \glt ‘Mum kept searching and shouting.’

Knowledge Point: The \textsc{limitative particle} nō\is{no ‘just’@nō ‘just’} ‘just, still’ (\sectref{sec:7.4.1}) occurs with zero and suffixed nominalised verbs\is{Verb!nominalised} (see \REF{ex:3.30} above).
Content 1: \gll Ko ha\ꞌumani \ꞌana \ꞌi te \textbf{kai} \textbf{iŋa} nō i te moa. | \gls PRF fed_up CONT at ART eat NMLZ just ACC ART chicken | \glt ‘He was fed up with eating only chicken.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Demonstrative!postnominal}\is{Demonstrative!postverbal}The \textsc{demonstrative} particles nei, ena and era. In the verb phrase, they co-occur with certain aspectual markers (\sectref{sec:7.6}); in the noun phrase, they co-occur with any determiner (\sectref{sec:4.6.3}). They do not occur with zero nominalisations\is{Verb!nominalised}, but they do occur with suffixed nominalisations\is{Noun!verbal}, for example in \REF{ex:3.48}, here repeated:
Content 1: \gll He hati te va\ꞌe pa he \textbf{hati} \textbf{iŋa} era \ꞌā o tō\ꞌoku va\ꞌe. | \gls NTR break ART foot like PRED break NMLZ DIST IDENT of POSS.1SG.O foot | \glt ‘He broke his leg, like I broke my leg (lit. like the breaking of my leg).’

Knowledge Point: The marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}\is{a (identity)@{\ꞌ}ā (identity)}\textit{/{\ꞌ}ana} occurs in the verb phrase as a continuous marker, co-occurring with certain aspectual markers (\sectref{sec:7.2.5.5}); in the noun phrase it serves as an identity marker (\sectref{sec:5.9}). It occurs with verbal nouns\is{Noun!verbal}, as illustrated in \REF{ex:3.48} above. In this context, where a comparison is involved, \textit{{\ꞌ}ā} is clearly an identity marker.
Content 1: \gll He hati te va\ꞌe pa he \textbf{hati} \textbf{iŋa} era \ꞌā o tō\ꞌoku va\ꞌe. | \gls NTR break ART foot like PRED break NMLZ DIST IDENT of POSS.1SG.O foot | \glt ‘He broke his leg, like I broke my leg (lit. like the breaking of my leg).’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Noun phrase elements} Nominalised verbs\is{Verb!nominalised} may also be accompanied by noun phrase particles. They may be preceded by any kind of determiner: the article te\is{te (article)}, demonstratives\is{Demonstrative} like tū as in \REF{ex:3.29} above, possessive pronouns\is{Pronoun!possessive} as in \REF{ex:3.27}, and the predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)} as in \REF{ex:3.48a}. Suffixed nominalisations tend to denote single instances of an event, so they may be countable: they can be modified by a numeral (see \REF{ex:3.18}), or by quantifiers\is{Quantifier} like \textit{\mbox{ta{\ꞌ}ato{\ꞌ}a}} ‘all’. The corpus does not contain examples of the plural marker ŋā\is{nza (plural marker)@ŋā (plural marker)} with verbal nouns\is{Noun!verbal}, but this may be accidental.
Content 1: \gll Ku mate atu \ꞌā a au \ꞌi te kata \ꞌi tū \textbf{haka} \textbf{paka} era i a ia. | \gls PRF die away CONT PROP 1SG at ART laugh at DEM CAUS conspicuous DIST ACC PROP 3SG | \glt ‘I laughed my head off (lit. died with laughing) because of his boasting.’
Content 2: \gll Tā\ꞌana \textbf{kī}: ta\ꞌe tātou hokotahi nō. | \gls POSS.3SG.A say CONNEG 1PL.INCL alone just | \glt ‘What she said, was: we are not alone.’
Content 3: \gll He hati te va\ꞌe pa he hati iŋa \textbf{era} \ꞌā o tō\ꞌoku va\ꞌe. | \gls NTR break ART foot like PRED break NMLZ DIST IDENT of POSS.1SG.O foot | \glt ‘He broke his leg, like I broke my leg (lit. like the breaking of my leg).’
Content 4: \gll He take\ꞌa mai ka teka \textbf{e} \textbf{rua} \textbf{haka} \textbf{teka} \textbf{iŋa} \ꞌi muri o te motu. | \gls NTR see hither CNTG revolve NUM two CAUS revolve NMLZ at near of ART islet | \glt ‘I saw (the bird) making two rounds near the islet.’

Knowledge Point: Any noun (i.e. entity word) can be used as the nucleus of a verb phrase. Usually, the noun is used in a predicative sense: a verb phrase headed by noun N signifies that the subject is or becomes N; it possesses or acquires property N. These constructions are somewhat similar to nominal predicates marked with he (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}), yet they are different: the noun may be preceded by any preverbal marker, e.g. an aspectual as in \REF{ex:3.55} or a negator as in \REF{ex:3.56}, and it may be followed by verb phrase particles such as \textit{rō {\ꞌ}ā} in \REF{ex:3.55}. Also, the clause may express a process (‘become’), while nominal predicates only express a state (‘be’).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌAi te nunui o te pa\ꞌahia \textbf{e} \textbf{toto} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā} e viri era. | \gls there ART PL:big of ART sweat IPFV blood EMPH CONT IPFV roll DIST | \glt ‘Big drops of sweat became blood and fell down.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kai} \textbf{oromatu\ꞌa} \textbf{hia} i oho rō mai era ki nei. | \gls NEG.PFV priest yet PFV go EMPH hither DIST to PROX | \glt ‘When he had not yet become a priest, he came here.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌAi te nunui o te pa\ꞌahia \textbf{e} \textbf{toto} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā} e viri era. | \gls there ART PL:big of ART sweat IPFV blood EMPH CONT IPFV roll DIST | \glt ‘Big drops of sweat became blood and fell down.’

Knowledge Point: In \sectref{sec:3.2.3.1.1} above (examples (\ref{ex:3.22}–\ref{ex:3.27})), a number of constructions are listed in which a verb is nominalised, even though they are main clauses expressing an event: the actor-emphatic construction, ko te + verb, et cetera. \sectref{sec:3.2.3.1.1} (\ref{ex:3.28}–\ref{ex:3.34}) lists a number of nominalised subordinate constructions, e.g. \textit{{\ꞌ}o te} + verb to indicate cause or reason. (As shown in \sectref{sec:11.6.4}, various other nominal constructions are used as well to express reason.)
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀ\ꞌana te \textbf{kai} i te me\ꞌe ririva ta\ꞌato\ꞌa. | \gls POSS.3SG.A ART eat ACC ART thing good:RED all | \glt ‘He (was the one who) ate all the best things.’
Content 2: \gll Tā\ꞌana \textbf{kī}: ta\ꞌe tātou hokotahi nō. | \gls POSS.3SG.A say CONNEG 1PL.INCL alone just | \glt ‘What she said, was: we are not alone.’
Content 3: \gll Ko koa rivariva \ꞌana te ŋā poki \ꞌo te \textbf{turu} haka\ꞌou o rāua ki te hāp\=\i. | \gls PRF happy good:RED CONT ART PL child because_of ART go_down again of 3PL to ART learn | \glt ‘The children are really happy because they go back to school.’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌIna he mā\ꞌeha mo \textbf{u\ꞌi} \textbf{iŋa} i te kai. | \gls NEG PRED light for see NMLZ ACC ART food | \glt ‘There was no light to see the food.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Complements} Motion verbs may be followed by a nominal Goal complement as in \REF{ex:3.59}, even though the goal is semantically an event (\sectref{sec:11.6.3}). As the example shows, the event may be expressed by a verb following the nominal complement. Likewise, perception verbs may be followed by a nominal object + a verbal clause, as in \REF{ex:3.60} (\sectref{sec:11.3.1.2}).
Content 1: \gll He iri ararua \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{rāua} \textbf{hoi} \ꞌa\ꞌaru mai. | \gls NTR ascend the_two to ART 3PL horse grab hither | \glt ‘Both of them went to grab their horse.’
Content 2: \gll He take\ꞌa \textbf{i} \textbf{a} \textbf{Hoto} \textbf{Vari} ka pū mai. | \gls NTR see ACC PROP Hoto Vari CNTG approach hither | \glt ‘He saw Hoto Vari approaching.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Arguments as possessives} In a number of constructions, verbal arguments – especially S and A – may be expressed as possessives, even when the verb is not nominalised. This is the default way to express the S/A argument in clauses introduced by mo as in \REF{ex:3.62} (\sectref{sec:11.5.1.2}); it commonly happens in relative clauses as in \REF{ex:3.63} (\sectref{sec:11.4.4}); and under certain conditions it happens in main clauses as in \REF{ex:3.64} (\sectref{sec:8.6.4.1}).
Content 1: \gll Mo haŋa \textbf{ō\ꞌou} mo \ꞌite a hē a au e ŋaro nei... | \gls if want POSS.2SG.O for know by CQ PROP 1SG IPFV disappear PROX | \glt ‘If you want to know where I disappear (then come with me).’
Content 2: \gll ¿He aha \textbf{te} \textbf{kōrua} me\ꞌe [i aŋa \ꞌi \ꞌApina]? | \gls ~NTR what ART 2PL thing ~PFV do at Apina | \glt ‘What did you do (lit. what [is] your thing did) in Apina?’
Content 3: \gll He kī \textbf{o} \textbf{tū} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{era}... | \gls NTR say of DEM old_woman DIST | \glt ‘The old woman said...’

Knowledge Point: Prototypical common nouns\is{Noun!common} denote classes of concrete, bounded entities, for example persons (taŋata) and objects (hare ‘house’, toki ‘adze’). Prototypical proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} are names of persons. The precise extent of each category can be deduced from the syntactic behaviour of nouns, with \REF{ex:3.1} and \REF{ex:3.3} above as main criteria: nouns preceded by the proper article\is{a (proper article)} a are proper nouns\is{Noun!proper}; nouns preceded by determiners like the article te are common nouns\is{Noun!common}. This will be explored in the next section.
Content 1: \gll He pōrekoreko \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{poki} \ꞌi Tāhai. | \gls NTR born:RED ART PL child at Tahai | \glt ‘Children were born in Tahai.’
Content 2: \gll ¿He parauti\ꞌa \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌamu} nei? | \gls ~PRED truth ART story PROX | \glt ‘Is this story true?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:3.3.2}.6~ Names of months}\is{Months, names of} Names of months always take the proper article\is{a (proper article)}, regardless which names are used: the old Rapa Nui names as in \REF{ex:3.78}, the modern \ili{English}-based names as in \REF{ex:3.79}, or \ili{Spanish} names as in \REF{ex:3.80}:
Content 1: \gll E tiaki \ꞌātā ki \textbf{a} \textbf{Hora~Nui}. | \gls EXH wait until to PROP September | \glt ‘You must wait until September.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI \textbf{a} \textbf{Noema} o nei matahiti \ꞌā i hoki haka\ꞌou ai ki nei henua. | \gls at PROP November of PROX year IDENT PFV return again PVP to PROX land | \glt ‘In November of this same year he returned again to this island.’
Content 3: \gll Ki oti te Tāpati nei he piri tātou \ꞌi \textbf{a} \textbf{marzo}. | \gls when finish ART Tapati PROX NTR join 1PL.INCL at PROP March | \glt ‘When the Tapati (= festival week) is finished we are close to March.’

Knowledge Point: Verbs may have zero, one, two or three arguments. Zero-argument verbs are, for example, words indicating a moment in time or the passage of time.\footnote{\label{fn:113}On zero-argument verbs, see \citet[267]{Dryer2007Clause}. Crosslinguistically, zero-argument verbs typically involve weather conditions (‘It rains’). In Rapa Nui however, weather terms are not zero-argument verbs: as discussed in \sectref{sec:3.2.2.1.2}, weather conditions are expressed by subject–predicate collocations, i.e. one-argument predicates.} \textit{{\ꞌ}Ōtea} ‘to dawn’ in \REF{ex:3.82} and ahiahi ‘to be evening’ in \REF{ex:3.83} do not have a subject or any other argument, whether overt or implied. The bracketed clause consists of a predicate only.
Content 1: \gll \obI \textbf{\ꞌōtea} era\,\cb he turu he oho a Kava... | \gls {\db}PFV dawn DIST NTR go_down NTR go PROP Kava | \glt ‘When it dawned, Kava went down...’
Content 2: \gll \obHe ahiahi\,\cb, he ma\ꞌoa te \ꞌumu. | \gls {\db}NTR afternoon NTR open ART earth_oven | \glt ‘(When) it was late afternoon, they opened the earth oven.’

Knowledge Point: Many verbs may be either transitive\is{Verb!intransitive} or intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive}, depending on whether an object is expressed or implied.\footnote{\label{fn:115}In this grammar, any clause in which a Patient/Theme argument is either expressed or implied, is considered transitive. See also Footnote \ref{fn:379} on p.~\pageref{fn:379} on transitivity.} For example, the verb kai ‘to eat’ is transitive\is{Verb!intransitive} when a certain (type of) food is mentioned or implied in the context: in \REF{ex:3.84} below it is transitive\is{Verb!transitive}; in \REF{ex:3.85} it is transitive\is{Verb!transitive} as well, even though the object is implicit (it has been mentioned just before); in \REF{ex:3.86} it is intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive}.\footnote{\label{fn:116}Whether a verb is transitive\is{Verb!transitive} or intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive} may have syntactic repercussions, even when no object is expressed. See the discussion on causativisation of transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verbs in \sectref{sec:8.12.3}, esp. examples \REF{ex:8.235} and \REF{ex:8.236}.}
Content 1: \gll Kai haŋa a Puakiva mo kai i tū kai era. | \gls NEG.PFV want PROP Puakiva for eat ACC DEM food DIST | \glt ‘Puakiva did not want to eat that food.’
Content 2: \gll Mo kai ō\ꞌou he mate koe. | \gls if eat POSS.2SG.O NTR die 2SG | \glt ‘If you eat (the poison), you will die.’
Content 3: \gll ¿Ko kai \ꞌā koe? | \gls ~PRF eat CONT 2SG | \glt ‘Have you eaten?’
Content 4: \gll He to\ꞌo mai te matu\ꞌa i te raŋo... He haka \ꞌamo \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{taŋata}. | \gls NTR take hither ART parent ACC ART support NTR CAUS carry to ART man | \glt ‘The father took the stretcher... He made the men carry (it).’
Content 5: \gll He haka \ꞌa\ꞌamu te aŋa i tō\ꞌona māmārū\ꞌau era ko Kena. | \gls PRED CAUS tell ART do ACC POSS.3SG.O grandmother DIST PROM Kena | \glt ‘She always made her grandmother Kena tell (stories).’

Knowledge Point: Now Rapa Nui also has “bare\is{Clause!relative!bare} relative clauses\is{Clause!relative}”, relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} in which the verb is not preceded by an aspect marker\is{Aspect marker} (\sectref{sec:11.4.5}). One could ask whether an adnominal adjective is structurally identical to the verb in a bare relative clause\is{Clause!relative}. After all, there are certain similarities between both, besides the absence of the aspect marker. For one thing, adnominal adjectives may be preceded by degree markers and followed by adverbs\is{Adverb} (\sectref{sec:5.7.3.2}), elements which also occur in verb phrases (\sectref{sec:7.3.2}; \sectref{sec:4.5.1}). Adjectives may enter into the comparative\is{Comparative} construction, but verbs occasionally enter into this construction as well (see \REF{ex:3.94} in \sectref{sec:7.3.2}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: When adjectives are used predicatively, these restrictions do not hold: not only are predicate adjectives preceded by an aspectual marker\is{Aspect marker}, they can be followed by evaluative markers, or by a directional\is{Directional} marker as in the following example:\footnote{\label{fn:135}Examples such as \REF{ex:3.98} are not very common, as time-stable properties are not naturally associated with directionality. In the example above, atu is used in the sense of extent (\sectref{sec:7.5.1.5}).}
Content 1: \gll Ku rikiriki \textbf{atu} \ꞌā te ika nei pē he tapatea \ꞌana. | \gls PRF small:PL:RED away CONT ART fish PROX like PRED kind_of_eel IDENT | \glt ‘These fish are quite small, just like tapatea.’

Knowledge Point: Nominally used adjectives usually do not have a nominalising\is{Nominalisation} suffix; in this respect they differ from verbs. For example, in \REF{ex:3.94} in \sectref{sec:3.5.1.3} above, rivariva is used as object of a verb of perception; in this context, verbs normally get a nominalising\is{Nominalisation} suffix (\sectref{sec:3.2.3.1}), but rivariva does not.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: } In one of these, the particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ata}\is{ata ‘more’@{\ꞌ}ata ‘more’} serves as index of comparison (‘more, -er’); it precedes the adjective expressing the parameter of comparison. This construction can be used whether the adjective is adnominal as in \REF{ex:3.112} or predicative as in \REF{ex:3.113}. The standard of comparison is expressed by ki\is{ki (preposition)} + noun phrase.
Content 1: \glll E ai rō \ꞌā... \obte~~~~~poki\,\cb \ob\ꞌata\,\cb \obnuinui\,\cb ... \obki~~a~~~~~~Taparahi\,\cb. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH CONT {\db}ART~~child {\db}more {\db}big ~ {\db}to~~PROP~~Taparahi | \gls ~ ~ ~ ~ ~COMPAREE ~INDEX ~PARAMETER ~ ~STANDARD
Content 2: \glll ¿\ob\ꞌAta\,\cb \obmaneŋe\,\cb \obkoe\,\cb \obki~~te~~~~~poki~~~era~~ai\,\cb? | \gls ~~~more {\db}medium_size {\db}2SG {\db}to~~ART~~child~~DIST~~there | \gls ~~~INDEX ~~PARAMETER ~~COMPAREE ~~STANDARD

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}Ata} also functions as a degree marker in front of event verbs (\sectref{sec:7.3.2}, where its etymology is also discussed). With verbs, it may also form a complete comparative\is{Comparative} construction, including a standard of comparison (see \REF{ex:7.94} on p.~\pageref{ex:7.94}).
Content 1: \gll ¡E Māria, \textbf{\ꞌata} ha\ꞌamaitai koe e te \ꞌAtua \textbf{ki} te ta\ꞌato\ꞌa ŋā vi\ꞌe. | \gls ~VOC Mary more bless 2SG AG ART God to ART all PL woman | \glt ‘Mary, you are more blessed by God than all women.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbial expressions like these often have an absolute sense. For example, in \REF{ex:3.130} ki raro indicates ‘down, in a lower direction’. In other cases, the locational\is{Locational} is interpreted relative to a second referent, which is implied. In \REF{ex:3.132}, the context makes clear that o ruŋa is to be interpreted with respect to an island.
Content 1: \gll He marere te hare \textbf{ki} \textbf{raro}. | \gls NTR scatter ART house to below | \glt ‘The house fell down.’
Content 2: \gll Me\ꞌe rahi te manu \textbf{o} \textbf{ruŋa}. | \gls thing many ART bird of above | \glt ‘There were many birds on (the island).’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the second preposition may be either i\is{i (preposition)} as in \REF{ex:3.133}, o\is{o (possessive prep.)} as in \REF{ex:3.134}, or a copy of the first preposition as in (\ref{ex:3.135}–\ref{ex:3.136}). When the first preposition is \textit{{\ꞌ}i} or o, the analysis of the second preposition is ambiguous: in \textit{{\ꞌ}i raro i} in \REF{ex:3.137}, the second preposition may be either a default preposition i, or a copy of the first preposition (\textit{{\ꞌ}i} and i are variants of the same preposition, see \sectref{sec:4.7.2}). The same is true for \textit{o tu{\ꞌ}a o} in \REF{ex:3.138}.
Content 1: \gll He uru te kurī ki roto i te hare. | \gls textsc{ntr} enter ART cat to inside at ART house | \glt ‘The cat entered into (lit. to inside) the house.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI te rua mahana i tu\ꞌu mai ai \textbf{ki} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} \textbf{o} Haŋa Kaokao. | \gls at ART two day PFV arrive hither PVP to front of Hanga Kaokao | \glt ‘On the second day, they arrived in front of Hanga Kaokao.’
Content 3: \gll He e\ꞌa \textbf{mai} \textbf{roto} \textbf{mai} te koro. | \gls NTR go_out from inside from ART feast_house | \glt ‘They went out of the feast house.’
Content 4: \gll He eke māua \textbf{ki} \textbf{ruŋa} \textbf{ki} te hoi. | \gls NTR go_up 1DU.EXCL to above to ART horse | \glt ‘We mounted (on top of) the horses.’
Content 5: \gll He \ꞌoka te pua \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{raro} \textbf{i} te rano \ꞌi Rano \ꞌAroi. | \gls NTR plant ART kind_of_plant at below at ART crater_lake at Rano Aroi | \glt ‘He planted pua down in the crater of Rano Aroi.’
Content 6: \gll Ko Meta te me\ꞌe \textbf{o} \textbf{tu\ꞌa} \textbf{o} Juan Hotu. | \gls PROM Meta ART thing of back of Juan Hotu | \glt ‘Meta is the one behind Juan Hotu.’

Knowledge Point: As \citet[54–55]{Clark1976} points out, all other Polynesian languages use either i or o as second preposition;\footnote{\label{fn:142}Vaitupu (a dialect of \ili{Tuvaluan}) is the only variety apart from Rapa Nui where both o and i are used, without apparent difference in meaning.} Rapa Nui is the only language in which the second preposition may be a copy of the first.\footnote{\label{fn:143}As \citet[56–57]{Clark1976} indicates, the copying construction could have arisen from cases like \REF{ex:3.137} or \REF{ex:3.138}: the second preposition, which originally was an invariable i or o, was reanalysed as a repetition of the first one. This reanalysis could have been facilitated by constructions like the following (quoted by Clark):
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌoka te pua \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{raro} \textbf{i} te rano \ꞌi Rano \ꞌAroi. | \gls NTR plant ART kind_of_plant at below at ART crater_lake at Rano Aroi | \glt ‘He planted pua down in the crater of Rano Aroi.’
Content 2: \gll Ko Meta te me\ꞌe \textbf{o} \textbf{tu\ꞌa} \textbf{o} Juan Hotu. | \gls PROM Meta ART thing of back of Juan Hotu | \glt ‘Meta is the one behind Juan Hotu.’

Knowledge Point: In older texts the copying strategy is used in an overwhelming majority of the cases. Not counting the ambiguous \textit{{\ꞌ}i} LOC i\is{i (preposition)} and o\is{o (possessive prep.)} LOC o constructions, the second preposition is a copy of the first in 93% of all PREP + LOC + PREP constructions in this corpus (768 out of 826). Thus, constructions like (\ref{ex:3.135}–\ref{ex:3.136}) are common in older texts, while constructions such as (\ref{ex:3.133}–\ref{ex:3.134}) are rare.
Content 1: \gll He e\ꞌa \textbf{mai} \textbf{roto} \textbf{mai} te koro. | \gls NTR go_out from inside from ART feast_house | \glt ‘They went out of the feast house.’
Content 2: \gll He eke māua \textbf{ki} \textbf{ruŋa} \textbf{ki} te hoi. | \gls NTR go_up 1DU.EXCL to above to ART horse | \glt ‘We mounted (on top of) the horses.’
Content 3: \gll He uru te kurī ki roto i te hare. | \gls textsc{ntr} enter ART cat to inside at ART house | \glt ‘The cat entered into (lit. to inside) the house.’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌI te rua mahana i tu\ꞌu mai ai \textbf{ki} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} \textbf{o} Haŋa Kaokao. | \gls at ART two day PFV arrive hither PVP to front of Hanga Kaokao | \glt ‘On the second day, they arrived in front of Hanga Kaokao.’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui the copying strategy is still in use, as illustrated by \REF{ex:3.136} above, but it has become relatively rare, occurring in only 10% of all nonambiguous cases (175 out of 1761).\footnote{\label{fn:144}This tendency is even stronger in the Bible translation, which is more recent than most of the newer texts: in the new Testament, the preposition is i or o in over 99% of the prepositions, with i in the overwhelming majority (88%).} And some of these are, on a closer look, not copies at all, but prepositions introducing a new constituent. The following example illustrates this:
Content 1: \gll He eke māua \textbf{ki} \textbf{ruŋa} \textbf{ki} te hoi. | \gls NTR go_up 1DU.EXCL to above to ART horse | \glt ‘We mounted (on top of) the horses.’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:3.160} shows, the verb used for a movement in the direction of the sea is turu\is{turu ‘to go down’} ‘go down’. This verb is always used for seaward movement, even when no vertical movement is involved. Note, however, that in the hilly landscape of Rapa Nui a movement towards the sea will often involve some downward movement.
Content 1: \gll He turu \textbf{ki} \textbf{tai} hāhaki rāua ko te poki. | \gls NTR go_down to sea gather_shellfish 2PL PROM ART child | \glt ‘She went down to the seashore to gather shellfish with her child.’

Knowledge Point: For example, \textit{ki {\ꞌ}uta}\is{uta ‘inland’@{\ꞌ}uta ‘inland’} either indicates a movement from sea to land as in \REF{ex:3.162}, or a movement from a place on land to a place further inland as in \REF{ex:3.163}. In the first case the verb tomo\is{tomo ‘to go ashore’} ‘go ashore’ is used, in the second case iri\is{iri ‘to go up’} ‘go up’.
Content 1: \gll He tomo te taŋata \textbf{ki} \textbf{\ꞌuta}. | \gls NTR go_ashore ART man to inland | \glt ‘The people went ashore.’
Content 2: \gll He iri tau kope era \textbf{ki} \textbf{\ꞌuta} ki te tau\ꞌa. | \gls NTR ascend DEM person DIST to inland to ART battle | \glt ‘That man went (further) inland to the battle.’

Knowledge Point: Kōnui ‘far, distant’ does not indicate an absolute point of reference, but any point far away from the reference point. The reference point may be the starting point of a movement as in \REF{ex:3.171}, or the place where the action takes place as in \REF{ex:3.172}.
Content 1: \gll He tere he piko a Manu \textbf{ki} \textbf{kōnui} era. | \gls NTR run NTR hide PROP bird to far DIST | \glt ‘Manu fled and hid far away.’
Content 2: \gll He u\ꞌi atu \textbf{mai} \textbf{kōnui} nei \ꞌā ko te pua\ꞌa ka teka, ka teka. | \gls NTR look away from far PROX IDENT PROM ART cow CNTG revolve CNTG revolve | % \largerpage

Knowledge Point: Like other locationals\is{Locational}, these words are preceded by prepositions, such as locative \textit{{\ꞌ}i} \REF{ex:3.173} or genitive o \REF{ex:3.174}:
Content 1: \gll Kai ha\ꞌuru mātou \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{\ꞌaŋapō}. | \gls NEG.PFV sleep 1PL.EXCL at last_night | \glt ‘We did not sleep last night.’
Content 2: \gll Te nu\ꞌu ruku \textbf{o} \textbf{\ꞌaŋanīrā} ko ai \ꞌana te raperape, te hi\ꞌo... | \gls ART people dive of today.PAST PROM exist CONT ART swimming_fin ART glass | \glt ‘Today’s divers have swimming fins, goggles...’
